<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 123, 637, 146]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 185]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 169, 247]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 213, 424, 259]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[859, 279, 905, 294]]<|/det|> 979/41 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[765, 304, 905, 319]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[758, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 391, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: List of formulae (MF19) <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 291, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 761, 466]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 464, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 480, 565, 497]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 511, 355, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 867, 544]]<|/det|> - If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 558, 482, 573]]<|/det|> - You should use a calculator where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 573, 881, 589]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 854, 620]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 636, 777, 653]]<|/det|> - Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\). <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 679, 214, 696]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 696, 388, 713]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 50. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 712, 730, 729]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
1 A block of mass 12 kg is being pulled by a rope up a rough plane. The plane is inclined at an angle of \(20^{\circ}\) above the horizontal. The rope pulling the block is parallel to a line of greatest slope of the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
plane. The coefficient of friction between the block and the plane is 0.4 . The acceleration of the block is \(2 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 152, 338, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the rope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
2

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 87, 669, 228]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 244, 918, 262]]<|/det|>
Three coplanar forces of magnitudes \(P \mathrm{~N}, 5 \mathrm{~N}\) and 10 N act at a point \(O\), as shown in the diagram. The resultant of the three forces has magnitude \(Q \mathrm{~N}\) and acts in a direction perpendicular to the force of

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 245, 292]]<|/det|>
magnitude \(P \mathrm{~N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 306, 424, 323]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(P\) and the value of \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
3

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 90, 813, 278]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 297, 918, 314]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the velocity-time graph of the motion of a cyclist. The graph consists of three straight line segments. The cyclist passes a point \(O\) with speed \(3 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) and then accelerates for 10 s with

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 326, 918, 344]]<|/det|>
constant acceleration \(0.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\). He then travels at constant speed for 30 s before decelerating, coming to rest at point \(P\), covering a distance of 80 m whilst decelerating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 372, 572, 392]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the total time taken for the journey from \(O\) to \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) On the given axes, sketch a displacement-time graph for the cyclist's journey from \(O\) to \(P\), showing on your graph the distances travelled after 10 s and 40 s .

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 118, 890, 497]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 587, 91]]<|/det|>
4 A lorry of mass 18000 kg is travelling along a straight road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
(a) On a horizontal section of the road, the power of the lorry's engine is constant. There is a constant resistance to motion of 1600 N .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 151, 918, 168]]<|/det|>
(i) The steady speed which the lorry can maintain with the engine working at power \(P \mathrm{~W}\) is \(30 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 195, 352, 210]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[152, 406, 918, 426]]<|/det|>
(ii) At an instant when the speed of the lorry is \(16 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\), its engine is working at a power of 40 kW .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 437, 565, 454]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of the lorry at this instant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 648, 918, 668]]<|/det|>
(b) When the lorry has reached a speed of \(20 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\), it begins to ascend a section of road inclined at an angle \(\alpha^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The engine now works at a power of 120 kW . There is no change in the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 682, 822, 698]]<|/det|>
lorry's speed as it ascends the hill. The constant resistance to motion remains 1600 N .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 710, 314, 725]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 910, 96]]<|/det|>
5 When a particle \(P\) of mass \(m \mathrm{~kg}\) has speed \(u \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\), its momentum is 4 Ns and its kinetic energy is 16 J .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 109, 460, 126]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the value of \(m\) and the value of \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 384, 921, 403]]<|/det|>
\(P\) is now projected on a smooth horizontal surface with speed \(v \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) directly towards a particle \(Q\) of mass 1.25 kg which is stationary. After \(P\) and \(Q\) collide, the velocity of \(P\) is \(w \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) and the velocity of

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 419, 614, 438]]<|/det|>
\(Q\) is \(2 w \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\). The loss of kinetic energy in the collision is 25 J .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 452, 457, 469]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the value of \(v\) and the value of \(w\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
6

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 87, 788, 218]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 236, 918, 253]]<|/det|>
Two particles, \(P\) and \(Q\), of masses 0.3 kg and 0.6 kg respectively, are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a smooth pulley fixed at a point \(B\) where the inclined planes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 267, 918, 284]]<|/det|>
\(A B\) and \(B C\) meet. \(P\) lies on the smooth plane \(A B\) which is inclined at an angle \(\theta^{\circ}\) to the horizontal where \(\sin \theta^{\circ}=0.4 . Q\) lies on the plane \(B C\) which is inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The string is taut and the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 298, 918, 315]]<|/det|>
particles can move on lines of greatest slope of the two planes (see diagram). The particles are released from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 343, 460, 362]]<|/det|>
(a) It is given that the plane \(B C\) is smooth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 374, 587, 393]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string and the acceleration of \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) It is given instead that the plane \(B C\) is rough. The work done against the frictional force when \(Q\) moves 2 m down the plane is 1.8 J . You should assume that \(P\) does not reach the pulley and that \(Q\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 105, 297, 120]]<|/det|>
does not reach \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 134, 816, 150]]<|/det|>
Use an energy method to find the speed of \(Q\) when it has moved 2 m down the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 921, 92]]<|/det|>
7 A particle \(X\) moves along a straight track, starting from a point \(O\) at time \(t=0\). The displacement of \(X\) from \(O\) at time \(t \mathrm{~s}\) is \(s \mathrm{~m}\), where \(s=3 t^{\frac{3}{2}}-6 t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 921, 143]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the time at which \(X\) is instantaneously at rest, and hence find the total distance travelled by \(X\) between \(t=0\) and \(t=16\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
A second particle \(Y\) moves along another straight track, starting from a point \(P\) at time \(t=0\). The acceleration of \(Y\) at time \(t \mathrm{~s}\) is \(a \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\), where \(a=0.8-0.6 t\). The velocity of \(Y\) when it leaves \(P\) is

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 195, 122]]<|/det|>
\(7.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 918, 153]]<|/det|>
(b) When the velocity of \(Y\) is \(-9.6 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\), show that the displacement of \(X\) from \(O\) is equal to the displacement of \(Y\) from \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 74, 567, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
